title: Paternal Metformin Use and Birth Defects
content: A study published in the Annals of Internal Medicine examined the effects of paternal exposure to three separate diabetes treatments during spermatogenesis on offspring. The study found that paternal metformin treatment was associated with elevated frequency of genital birth defects in male offspring, as well as a higher frequency of all-category birth defects irrespective of offspring sex. These associations were not observed in the offspring of men who ceased metformin treatment prior to the 3-month preconception window, nor did the authors find any effect on unexposed siblings of exposed offspring. The study was robustly designed by observational standards, utilizing vast registry data to exclude cases of maternal diabetes or essential hypertension and to adjust for confounds.

title: Limitations of the Study
content: The study has significant limitations, including the absence of data on medication compliance and glycemic control. The study was underpowered, and even a small error in assessing exposure might have made the difference in whether or not the result was significant. The lack of glycemic control data raises the possibility that this variable constituted a major confound for which the authors could not adjust. The study was also underpowered for sulfonylurea, and insufficient power might account for the lack of observed association between paternal sulfonylurea exposure and the specific subclass of genital defects in male offspring.

title: Correlation vs. Causation
content: The study has shown an association between paternal metformin exposure and offspring birth defects, but it cannot show a causal pathway linking the two variables because of the “third variable problem”. T2D is a complex disease affecting the entire body, and any number of affected pathways might impact offspring health. More studies are needed.

title: Lack of Existing Data on Paternal Metformin Exposure and Birth Defects
content: Because, in contrast to the association between statin use and cardiovascular risk, we have virtually no existing data on paternal metformin exposure and birth defects – no large body of consistent literature exists to contravene these results.

title: Uncharted Territory in Research
content: The trend toward an ever-younger average age at T2D diagnosis means that the use of diabetes drugs during reproductive years, especially in men, is relatively uncharted territory in research.

title: Further Investigation Needed
content: The results of this study may ultimately prove to be a false association – or they could be a canary in a coalmine. More thorough, randomized, interventional studies will be necessary to determine which is the case.

title: Caution Needed for Diabetes Patients Trying to Have Children
content: In the meantime, physicians should exercise caution when considering treatment plans for diabetes patients trying to have children, taking into account both the possible effects of metformin and the clear effects of uncontrolled diabetes on reproductive health.
